title: 42-D
statement: D. Strange towntime limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstdinoutputstdoutVolodya has recently visited a very odd town. There areNtourist attractions in the town and every two of them are connected by a bidirectional road. Each road has some travel price (natural number) assigned to it and all prices are distinct. But the most striking thing about this town is that each city sightseeing tour has the same total price! That is, if we choose any city sightseeing tour — a cycle which visits every attraction exactly once — the sum of the costs of the tour roads is independent of the tour. Volodya is curious if you can find such price system with all road prices not greater than 1000.InputInput contains just one natural number (3 ≤N≤ 20) — the number of town attractions.OutputOutput should containNrows containingNpositive integer numbers each — the adjacency matrix of the prices graph (thus,j-th number ini-th row should be equal to the price of the road between thej-th and thei-th attraction). Diagonal numbers should be equal to zero. All numbers should not be greater than 1000. All prices should be positive and pairwise distinct. If there are several solutions, output any of them.ExamplesInput3Output0 3 43 0 54 5 0

processed.result:
Given a number $N$ ($3 \le N \le 20$), find a matrix representing a graph with $N$ nodes.  

* Each row and column of the matrix represents a node.
* The value in the $i$-th row and $j$-th column represents the cost of traveling between node $i$ and node $j$.
* The cost of traveling between a node and itself is 0.
* All costs are positive integers less than or equal to 1000.
* All costs are distinct.
* The sum of the costs of traveling around any cycle in the graph is the same. 

Output the matrix. If there are multiple solutions, output any one.

You are given a number N.  Create a grid of numbers representing connections between N things. Each connection has a cost. The cost of going around in a loop visiting all N things must be the same no matter which path you take.  All costs must be between 1 and 1000 and different from each other.
